column1: The pupil is the black part in the center of the eye.
Babies born with different sized pupils may not have any underlying disorder.
Unequal pupil sizes of more than 1 mm that develop later in life and do NOT return to equal size may be a sign of an eye, brain, blood vessel, or nerve disease.

Other causes of unequal pupil sizes may include: - Aneurysm - Bleeding inside the skull caused by head injury - Brain tumor or abscess - Excess pressure in one eye caused by glaucoma - Increased intracranial pressure, because of brain swelling, intracranial hemorrhage, acute stroke, or intracranial tumor - Infection of membranes around the brain (meningitis or encephalitis) - Migraine headache - Seizure (pupil size difference may remain long after seizure is over) - Tumor, mass, or lymph node in the upper chest or lymph node causing pressure on a nerve may cause decreased sweating, a small pupil, or drooping eyelid all on the affected side (Horner syndrome) - Diabetic occulomotor nerve palsy
Your provider will perform a physical exam and ask questions about your symptoms and medical history, including: - Is this new for you or have your pupils ever been different sizes before?
- Do you have other vision problems such as blurred vision, double vision, or light sensitivity?
- Do you have other symptoms such as headache, nausea, vomiting, fever, or stiff neck?
